body.p: How do you think common treatments for rheumatoid arthritis affect the rest of the body?

multiple_choice.choice: Lupus, an autoimmune disorder, may be caused

response.feedback: Correct. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) involves the body's own immune system attacking stressed cartilage. Thus, to treat RA, the immune system must be suppressed. With a weakened immune system, there is an increased risk of infection.
Incorrect. Treatments for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) usually try to reduce the symptom of joint pain.
Incorrect. Some hormonal therapies for rheumatoid arthritis (RA) can increase the risk of certain types of fracture, but generally this is not an issue.
Incorrect. Lupus is another autoimmune disorder, and many times rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and lupus are treated the same way.

part.hint: Treatments for autoimmune diseases reduce production of the immune cells that attack healthy tissue.
